Spearman’s rho correlation analysis indicated significant and strong positive relationships between perceived usefulness and behavioral intention and between perceived ease of use and behavioral intention. These findings suggest that although athletes are familiar with technology in general, they have not fully explored the use of generative AI tools like ChatGPT in the context of fitness planning. The study highlights the importance of increasing awareness and guided use of ChatGPT to support its adoption in athletic training, particularly for those with limited access to professional coaching.

title: Confidential Data Aggregation in IoT Systems: Ensuring Privacy Without Compromising Utility
authors: Apoorva Talwar, Pradeep Semwal, Ravi Singh, Pardeep Kumar, GD Makkar, Pratham Verma, Nitesh Kumar
abstract: The widespread integration of Internet of Things (IoT) devices has had a significant impact on many facets of contemporary society, leading to the emergence of intelligent home automation systems. However, concerns about data privacy, security, and social consequences have also followed the increased use of IoT technologies. The primary objective of this research thesis is to analyse and provide workable solutions for the complex issues associated with IoT-based applications, namely in the field of smart home automation. The study starts by thoroughly analysing popular Internet of Things (IoT) devices, paying particular attention to security vulnerabilities and potential attack locations. Vulnerabilities can be found and suitable mitigation techniques can be developed by thoroughly examining the firmware of the device, communication protocols, authentication procedures, and encryption methods.

title: Smart Learning Environment Design: AI Enhanced Drone Photogrammetry Systems for Participatory Architectural Education
authors: Jordi Rábago, Antonio Juárez, Lesly Pliego
publish: 2025 International Workshop on Artificial Intelligence and Education (WAIE)
abstract: This study demonstrates the educational potential of integrating artificial intelligence (AI) with drone photogrammetry in architectural education through a participatory learning approach. Conducted within the course “Investigación y Proyecto Arquitectónico” at Tecnologico de Monterrey, the research involved architecture students using advanced technologies to analyze segregated urban areas in Mexico. The methodology employed DJI Phantom 4 RTK drones equipped with high-resolution cameras to capture comprehensive aerial imagery, processing 747 images covering $0.195 \mathrm{~km}^{2}$ with $2.15 \mathrm{~cm} /$ pixel ground sampling distance. Data was processed using Pix4D software integrated with AI technologies including convolutional neural networks (CNNs), SuperPoint/SuperGlue networks, and PointNet++ for enhanced spatial analysis. Educational outcomes were measured using the Motivated Strategies for Learning Questionnaire (MSLQ), revealing high intrinsic motivation (M=6.57, SD=0.53) and extrinsic motivation (M=6.43, SD=0.79) among participating students. The study demonstrates that AI-enhanced drone photogrammetry not only improves technical competencies but also fosters critical thinking, data interpretation, and systems understanding essential for modern urban planning practice.

title: Performance Benchmarking of Machine Learning, Deep Learning, and Transformer Models for Context-Aware Sentiment Analysis on Informal Social Media Text
authors: Muhammad Awais, Khawaja Muhammad Anees
publish: 2025 International Conference on Engineering &amp; Computing Technologies (ICECT)
abstract: Popularity of Natural Language Processing (NLP) has been increasing because of its importance while dealing with social media when sentiment analysis is required to enable machines to read and comprehend human sentiments in written data. Different machine learning, deep learning and transformer-based models are implemented in this study with the aim of sentiment analysis. Tf-idf (Term Frequency-Inverse Document Frequency) and Bow (Bag of Words) techniques were used to process text while performing analysis. We compared different machine learning (Naive bayes, SVM), deep learning (CNN, LSTM), and transformer (BERT, GPT, Roberta) models to carry out context-sensitive sentiment analysis on 100 k Twitter post. Performance bechnmarking and evalaution of Models was carried out based on Accuracy, Precision, Recall, F1, ROC-AUC and training time. The highest accuracy was reported by RoBERTa (93.2%), followed by BERT (91.8%), GPT (90.1%), LSTM (88.4%) and CNN (85.3%). SVM and Naive Bayes were at the bottom with accuracies of 82.6% and 78.2%. Findings indicate the benefit of contextual transformers on informal, sarcasm-prone text, at the cost of a trade-off in training cost. Although, the great accuracy of machine learning models, it is was not easy to gauge and comprehend instances of sarcasm, irony and other forms of contextual slangs in written comments. The study also proposes sentiment analysis on multilingual and multimodal materials which would combine text, images, speech and videos. We are optimistic that in future we will be able to implement lightweight transformers such as distilbert and albert that do not need much memory but their work will be as accurate as before.

title: Curriculum Learning in Medical Image Analysis
authors: Riadh Meghatria, Djamel Gaceb, Fayçal Touazi
publish: 2025 International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Innovative Applications (AIIA)
abstract: Deep learning has revolutionized medical image analysis (MIA), offering unprecedented capabilities in diagnostics, prognosis, and treatment planning. However, its full potential is constrained by inherent challenges of medical data, including scarcity of large-scale annotated datasets, significant class imbalance, and the lack of model robustness to data distribution shifts. Curriculum learning (CL), a training paradigm inspired by human pedagogy, addresses these challenges by systematically structuring the learning process from easy to hard examples. This study presents a domain-focused review of CL in MIA. We synthesize how CL has been applied across diverse medical imaging tasks such as lesion detection, segmentation, and disease staging, demonstrating consistent gains in efficiency, robustness, and predictive accuracy. To provide structure to this field, we compile a taxonomy that categorizes CL approaches by their underlying difficulty criteria and learning paradigms. We further discuss open challenges and highlight promising avenues for future research, including the use of large pre-trained models, multi-modal data integration, and federated learning. By consolidating current evidence and perspectives, this study offers researchers and practitioners a comprehensive resource on CL in medical imaging and underscores its potential to advance clinically reliable AI systems.

title: Advancements in Ovarian Cancer Subtype Classification and Outlier Detection: A Comprehensive Survey of Machine Learning Approaches and Clinical Applications
authors: P.Rama Mohanrao, G. Zayaraz
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Intelligent Systems for Cybersecurity (ISCS)
abstract: Ovarian cancer is a very heterogeneous disease and, therefore, it is difficult to diagnose, which makes it necessary to clearly categorize the subtype in order to achieve further progress in patient care. The existing classification systems do not effectively use large amounts of molecular and clinical data, uncovering the best performance in the detection of cancer subtypes and in the detection of outliers. The presented literature review presents more than 20 articles published between 2000 and 2024 to review the latest methods of machine learning in the process of classifying subtypes of ovarian cancer and detecting outliers. The major shortcoming of current models is that they do not effectively combine multi-omics data, including genomic, transcriptomic and proteomic profiles, which are essential in improving the accuracy of the classification. Also, current methods of outlier detection often fail to focus on the clinical importance of uncommon subtypes of ovarian cancer, which may be deprived of significant information about the disease. This review will systematize the recent studies in three key directions: (1) development of sophisticated classification algorithms based on extensive molecular and clinical data, (2) development of new outlier detection algorithms to detect rare or unusual cases, and (3) the use and validation of machine learning models in clinical care. The two methodologies are considered based on the ability of the approach to generate clinically actionable information, and to improve individualized treatment plans specifically. Through the evaluation of these developments, this survey shows that the state-of-the-art machine learning solutions can help to fill existing gaps in the classification of subtypes of ovarian cancer and detecting outliers. It further pre-empts the work to come to incorporate computational models into practical clinical environments to eventual enhancements in the accuracy of diagnosis and improved patient outcomes by means of precision medicine.

title: Design and Implementation of a Conversational AI Platform for Medical Appointment Management
authors: Chithirala Bala Subramanyam, Garimidi SubbaRao, Kannekanti Maanasa, Juttu Suresh, P. Venkateswarlu Reddy, D. Ganesh
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Evolutionary Computing and Mobile Sustainable Networks (ICECMSN)
abstract: In this work, design and implemention of a Conversational AI Platform of Medical Appointment Management that will be automated to schedule patients with the help of Natural Language Processing (NLP) and intelligent scheduling algorithms. The system is built on the Rasa framework and connected with a real-time database, MySQL, which provides users with the possibility to book, reschedule, and cancel the appointments using natural dialogue. Experimental analysis on 200 simulated interactions showed that it decreased the time to book by 72 percent, reduced no-show rates by 37 percent, and increased user satisfaction by 24 percent over manual procedures. The findings affirm that conversational AI can be a significant contributor to operational efficiency and patient participation in the e-health setting.

title: Architectural Design of an Asymmetric Wargaming System Based on Intelligent Blue Force
authors: Xin Yang, Shu-Hong Liu, Yan-Lin Wu, Rui Tang
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Computer Engineering (ICAICE)
abstract: This paper addresses the asymmetric wargaming environment found in command support exercises, such as those for information and communications, where the Red and Blue sides possess different service branch identities and missions. It analyzes the challenges faced by traditional wargaming due to the lack of a professional Blue Force. To enhance the realism and effectiveness of these exercises, this paper proposes an architectural design for an asymmetric wargaming system based on an intelligent Blue Force. This architecture integrates key modules for intelligent Blue Force generation, asymmetric rule modeling, dynamic environmental interaction, and multidimensional evaluation. By constructing an intelligent Blue Force with an asymmetric cognitive model, a hybrid decision engine, and a continuous learning mechanism, and by designing rules and environments that support cross-domain confrontation, this system aims to provide a highly realistic, intensely competitive, and professional opposition environment for the Red side, who participates as support personnel. This environment effectively trains and hones the Red side's capabilities in information support and system protection.

title: A Population-Based Computational Framework for Analyzing and Mitigating Project Management Delays in Smart Grid Development
authors: Ijaz Ahmed, Muhammad Asif, Muhammad Khalid
publish: 2025 IEEE PES 17th Asia-Pacific Power and Energy Engineering Conference (APPEEC)
abstract: This paper highlights the significance of bi-objective optimization in project management and the potential of dynamic programming approaches to simplify complex industrial management situations. The study investigates the relationships between variables inside systems by employing algorithmic comparisons and the analytic hierarchy approach, so offering valuable insights into the efficacy of project management. The statistics reveals a stark reality: a mere 20.5% of projects are finished prior to the designated date. The occurrence of delays in most projects underscores the importance of project managers employing bi-objective optimization methodologies. To deal with the inherent challenges and uncertainties, the study suggests implementing a wide range of these tactics, which will ultimately enhance the success rates of projects.

title: A Scalable Hybrid LES-ANN Framework for Wake Prediction in Yawed Wind Turbine Arrays
authors: Kiran Perkins, Mahdi Erfanian Nakhchi
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Environment Friendly Energies and Applications (EFEA)
abstract: This study presents a scalable hybrid framework combining Large Eddy Simulation (LES) and Artificial Neural Networks (ANNs) for fast and accurate prediction of yawed wind turbine wakes. High-fidelity LES using the Actuator Disk Method (ADM) was conducted for tandem NREL-5MW turbines under yaw angles of 0°–40° and spacings of 3D–10D. The resulting velocity fields trained spacing-specific ANNs with adaptive yaw-weighted loss functions. The networks reproduced LES wake structures with mean relative errors below 7% while reducing computation time from 17.2 hours per LES run to 0.16 seconds. The model accurately captured wake deflection, recovery, and velocity deficits across configurations, achieving a 400,000× speed-up over LES. This hybrid LES-ANN framework offers a robust and computationally efficient tool for large-scale wind farm optimisation and wake control analysis.

title: Sparse Matrix Factorization for Scalable Machine Learning in Cloud Environments
authors: Srinivasu Yalamati
publish: 2025 International Conference on NexGen Networks and Cybernetics (IC2NC)
abstract: Demand for intelligent and versatile resource management techniques has increased with the proliferation of cloud computing and acceleration of industry adoption of microservice-style architectures. Dynamic, heterogenous, and dynamic workloads encountered by large-scale cloud systems are commonly not appropriate to be served by classic static or rule-based orchestration systems. AISF is a decentralized intelligent orchestration architecture that exploits predictive modeling and mutants-enabled deep reinforcement learning for contextually-aware, real-time resource allocation. In order to forecast load dynamics and dynamically re-distribute resources automatically using hierarchical control loops, including always evaluating system telemetry data, the AISF architecture makes use of learning agents that are deployed directly at service fabric level. AISF surpasses other baselines that include static-auto scaling and single-agent reinforcement learning in Google Cluster Workload Traces. It maintains 98.6% SLA satisfaction and demonstrates up to 25% resources saving, 40% latency reduction, and 21.9% energy expenditure mitigation. The model also possesses advantages of the better scalability, faster policy convergence, fault tolerance through distributed multi-agent coordination. AISF realizes energy-efficient and greening of cloud by the help of prediction with energy-awareness to stimulate carbon-conscious operation. The proposed solution positions AI as a fundamental power supply for future intelligent infrastructure management solutions and is a major step toward self-learning, self-healing, and self-optimization in the cloud.

title: Behind the Words: Unmasking Bias Lurking in LLMs and Data
authors: Naina Dhingra, Gargi Kale, Harshada Chavan, Sandhya Arora
abstract: This study examines hidden biases in large language models (LLMs). Three popular models-RoBERTa, BERT, and GPT-2-were evaluated using StereoSet, CrowS-Pairs, and Indian-BhED, datasets designed to expose biases. Our comparative analysis reveals clear variations in how these models encode and reproduce bias, underscoring the difficulty of mitigation. The results highlight the need for bias-aware evaluation. By contributing empirical evidence, this work advances the discussion on ethical AI and points to directions for building more responsible language technologies.

title: A Multi-Dimensional Extended TOF Material Classification Technique Based on Deep Convolutional Networks
authors: Lianzi Wang, Zhibin Liu, Miguel Heredia Conde
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Image Processing Workshops (ICIPW)
abstract: The multi-dimensional data acquired by a Time-of-Flight (ToF) camera successfully captures the material-dependent responses to modulated light, demonstrating excellent recognition performance in material classification tasks. Additionally, the material recognition technology integrated with deep learning has gradually become a focal point in current intelligent recognition research. However, when confronted with complex real material data exhibiting variable poses, the existing models reveal instability in the classification task. In response, we propose a multidimensional extended deep convolutional network for ToF-based material classification, building on our previous work. This approach incorporates observation angle information to enhance the ability to classify different materials while retaining the frequency domain information of the Fourier features, extends the dimension of features in the spatial domain and introduces a residual structure in the Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) to prevent the degradation of feature information. Through various analyses of multiple-materials datasets, we find that the method proposed in this paper achieves accurate real material classification by streamlining the network structure and reducing data processing.

title: Comparative Analysis of Fault Detection Techniques for Edge Enabled Smart Power Grids
authors: Jayashree Kulkarni
publish: 2025 International Conference on NexGen Networks and Cybernetics (IC2NC)
abstract: The increasing complexity of modern power grids and utilization of renewable sources of energy necessitate faster and more reliable methods of fault detection. Conventional centralized monitoring tends to be delayed, suffers from bandwidth constraints, and is not scalable. Edge computing presents a convincing alternative due to data analysis near the source. This research explores how edge computing can enhance power grid fault detection, with an emphasis on how rapid fault detections are avoided. There is a comparison with conventional cloud-based systems with improved response times, energy consumption, and system reliability. Various fault detection methods, such as Wavelet Transform-based thresholding, Zscore anomaly detection, and Isolation Forest algorithm are compared. The performance indicates that although the Z-score did not detect transient disturbances and the Isolation Forest detected more anomalies (with more false advantages), the Wavelet Transform approach was the best performing and computationally most efficient for edge nodes and thus suitable for real-time fault detection in power networks.

title: Enhance Tool Invocation with Large Language Models through Cluster-Augmented Demonstration Sampling
authors: Guoliang Hu, Liang Qian, Houlong Xiong
publish: 2025 IEEE 4th International Conference on Computing, Communication, Perception and Quantum Technology (CCPQT)
abstract: With the rapid development of large language models (LLMs), their integration with external tools has become a key research area, greatly enhancing their applicability in real-world scenarios. However, a core challenge lies in enabling LLMs to accurately and efficiently invoke these tools while adhering to precise structured output formats. Prevailing approaches, which predominantly depend on instruction tuning and reinforcement learning, often overlook the potential of in-context learning and exhibit limited generalization across diverse tools and contexts, underscoring the demand for more adaptable and robust solutions. To tackle this issue, we propose a novel framework that enhances tool invocation by combining clustering and retrieval strategy, namely cluster-augmented demonstration retrieval (CA-DR) mechanism that significantly improves the tool invocation accuracy, leading to an average 25.8% improvement in coarse-grained accuracy over baselines on ToolACE and BFCL benchmarks. By considering both the relevance and diversity of demonstrations, our approach effectively improves the few-shot capabilities of LLMs. Evaluation across multiple different types and scales of LLMs show that our method achieves relatively high tool invocation accuracy while maintaining high efficiency.

title: Design and Analysis of SRAM Circuits at 45nm Technology Using Sleeper Cells
authors: Niveditha, G K Shashank, R R Sumanth, Priyadarshini K Desai, N Hemanth Prasad
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Computing, Semiconductor, Mechatronics, Intelligent Systems and Communications (COSMIC)
abstract: The VLSI technology has evolved from 180 nm to 45 nm technology. In this evolution process power consumption and delay reduction are considered to be major requirements to be met. Any VLSI circuit is made up of many subunits, but it is known that the memory unit is considered to be one among the circuits, that consume major power and are responsible for delay operation. The memory unit majorly requires hold time to switch between read and write operations; that is the reason why the memory unit consumes the most power. In order to reduce the power consumption and improve the speed, sleeper cells can be introduced. In this work, initially SRAM is constructed using 3T, 6T & 9T technology. The power and delay measurements for read, write, and hold are carried out. Further, sleeper cells are introduced. Basically, a sleeper cell is constructed using PMOS, NMOS, and a combination of both. Power and delay performance of the SRAM memory unit is done with the deployment of the sleeper cell, without affecting the read, write, and hold operation. Through the experimentation it observed that the impact of adding NMOS, PMOS, and a combination of both is a significant reduction in leakage power in the majority of setups, along with a noticeable increase in speed during read and write operations. The work concludes that the sleeper cell composed of NMOS and PMOS appeared to balance speed and power savings the best during the sleeper cell analysis process in comparison with sleeper cell designed exclusively by PMOS and NMOS. With the introduction of sleeper cells made up of both NMOS and PMOS, a 90% reduction in power leakage is achieved. The obtained results clearly show that the deployment of sleeper transistors in SRAM designs can result in a memory unit that is more energy-efficient for modern SoCs and portable electronics.

title: Intelligent Three-Phase Imbalance Optimization Considering Participation Willingness of Flexible Resources: A Deep Learning Approach
authors: Xin Chen, Zheling Zhou, Weisheng Xu, Hongshi Chen, Xiang Zheng, Yingmou Chen
publish: 2025 13th International Conference on Smart Grid and Clean Energy Technologies (ICSGCE)
abstract: With the rapid penetration of distributed energy resources and single-phase loads in distribution networks, three-phase imbalance has emerged as a critical power quality issue affecting system efficiency and equipment lifespan. Traditional imbalance mitigation approaches often overlook user participation willingness and the heterogeneous characteristics of different flexible resources, leading to suboptimal performance and low user satisfaction. This paper proposes an intelligent three-phase imbalance optimization method that considers the participation willingness of various flexible resources including residential air conditioners, commercial air conditioners, electric vehicles, water heaters, and distributed energy storage systems. A Long Short-Term Memory neural network is employed to predict user participation willingness based on historical behavior patterns, economic incentives, and temporal characteristics. A multi-objective optimization framework is developed to balance imbalance mitigation and user comfort through coordinated control strategies. The proposed elastic willingness guidance mechanism dynamically adjusts incentive strategies based on three-phase imbalance severity levels. Simulation results on a typical distribution network demonstrate that the proposed method reduces three-phase imbalance violations while maintaining user comfort levels above acceptable thresholds, achieving improvements in power quality and user satisfaction compared to conventional approaches.

title: A Hybrid Explainable Deep Learning Model for Chronic Disease Risk Stratification using Multivariate Electronic Health Records
authors: T.Dhanalakshmi, Benasir Begam.F, K. Logu, A.Jegatheesan, Karpagam V, Narenthirakumar Appavu
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Evolutionary Computing and Mobile Sustainable Networks (ICECMSN)
abstract: This work aims to meet the need for easy risk rating in chronic diseases by proposing a time-based deep-learning technique for analysing large electronic health record, or EHR, data, therefore promoting equal medical access and sustainable healthcare innovation. It maintains openness and transparency while analysing the medical records of patients over an extended period to help predict how a disease will progress and figure out the best approach to break up patient groups according to risk. By involving chronology and attention mechanisms, the model can make precise predictions and offer medically relevant explanations for its decisions. Its efficacy in identifying high-risk patients and facilitating early intervention is demonstrated by research using actual EHR data. Additionally, by supporting AI-driven, accessible, and environmentally friendly medical solutions, it is appropriate for healthcare institutions with limited equipment and aligns with SDG 3 (Good Nutrition and Well-Being), SDG 9 (Industry, Innovation, as well as Infrastructures), as well as SDG 10 (Reduced Inequalities.

title: Early Detection of Apraxia of Speech in Children using MATLAB
authors: Dr Abha Dargar, Narisetty Gautam Babu, Somisetty Venakata Sumanth, Kosuri Satya Deeven Kumar
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Evolutionary Computing and Mobile Sustainable Networks (ICECMSN)
abstract: Childhood Apraxia of Speech (CAS) is a rare neurological disorder that impacts a child’s ability to coordinate the precise muscle movements required for speech. Detecting CAS at an early stage can significantly improve therapeutic outcomes. This paper presents a Convolutional Neural Network (CNN)-based approach for the automatic detection of Apraxia of Speech using spectrogram representations of children’s speech samples. The dataset consists of 150 audio recordings (100 normal and 50 apraxia), each 10-15 seconds long, processed in MATLAB. The system converts raw audio into standardized spectrogram segments and trains a CNN to classify them as either Normal or Apraxia. The model achieved an accuracy of 75–78%, showing that spectrogram-based CNN models can efficiently detect speech irregularities without handcrafted features like MFCCs. The results indicate the potential of deep learning-based speech analysis in assisting clinicians with early, objective, and automated diagnosis.

title: Domain-Adapted Video Frame Interpolation for Atmospheric Satellite Imagery
authors: Anson Saju George, T. Jemima Jebaseeli
publish: 2025 International Conference on NexGen Networks and Cybernetics (IC2NC)
abstract: Video Frame Interpolation (VFI) is an essential method for improving scientific and atmospheric visuals. The advanced VFI models trained on general video datasets struggle when directly used on specialized satellite images because of a substantial domain shift. The non-linear, flexible movement of clouds and other atmospheric events create significant visual distortions and blurriness that conventional models struggle to manage. This research addresses this challenge. First, a baseline is established by demonstrating a well-known VFI model trained on generic data that fails to produce coherent results on the specialized Weather Map Service (WMS) imagery. Second, a robust and effective transfer learning framework is introduced. This involves fine-tuning the pre-trained model on the WMS dataset using a novel custom loss function specifically designed to address the non-rigid dynamics of the cloud motion. The experiments show a significant improvement in the performance for satellite imagery. This suggests a refined model that significantly diminishes artifacts and improves perceptual quality, surpassing the standard baseline by a considerable margin on quantitative measures such as PSNR and SSIM, along with visual comparisons in terms of quality. This study validates that domain adaptation is a significant phase for utilizing VFI in scientific contexts and offers a robust, demonstrable method for interpolating intricate atmospheric phenomena.

title: The Personalization-Privacy Paradox in AI-Driven E-Commerce: A Consumer Trust Perspective
authors: Dhrishya Shetty, D K Sreekantha
abstract: Online shopping, the most widely used by people across the world. In this digital era, AI plays a very important role in online retail, specially in giving personalized experience to each customer. But it faces many challenges, one of which is privacy of customer information. The choices or information of the customer is a major concern in today's world. How the details of customers is being used to make personalised experiences. and also how their data is being stored. This causes conflict for marketers who have to balance privacy and the choices of customers. The key suggestions to build and retain customer trust by improving data handling transparency, using marketing methods that does cause discomfort to customers, and ensuring ethical data practices. The study goes through the importance of maintaining a balance between ethical and privacy standards and AI innovation.

title: Generative Adversarial Networks(GANs) for AI-Based Wireless Security Detection in Cloud Environments
authors: C. Nithyaprabha, M Keerthi, N Madesh, K Mathiarasu, R Naveenkumar
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Intelligent Systems for Cybersecurity (ISCS)
abstract: The threat of cyberattacks is growing due to the wide use of wireless technologies in the cloud-based infrastructures that demand effective intrusion detection systems. The paper describes a Generative Adversarial Network (GAN)-based system of artificial intelligence (AI)-based wireless security monitoring that will be more accurate, scalable and able to respond in real-time. The model also requires a Wasserstein GAN with Gradient Penalty (WGAN-GP) structure to generate adversarial traffic patterns to provide a reasonable training of the discriminator that boosts its sensitivity to both known and zero-day threats. The experimental tests have shown that the suggested model has a detection accuracy of 96.8, an average inference time of 95 ms, and the detection latency is reduced by 34% relative to other traditional intrusion detection systems. In addition, the system identifies zero-day threats including spoofing and replay attacks with more than 90 percent completeness, which makes them resilient to dynamic threats. These findings confirm how GANs could be used to further enhance the security infrastructure in wireless, and users can count on these scalable and dependable infrastructures as a solution to the cloud-based network.

title: Design of Arbitrary-Ratio Microwave Power Divider Based on Artificial Neural Network
authors: Guo Cheng, Tongzhou Xiang, Jiani Xue, Jiale Gao, Cong Xu, Yanghui Wu
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Computer Engineering (ICAICE)
abstract: To simplify the design process of microwave power dividers, this paper proposes a deep neural network (DNN)-based design method for microwave power dividers with arbitrary power division ratios. Taking a one-to-sixteen Wilkinson power divider as an example, a data set containing characteristic parameters such as micro strip line width, length, and isolation resistor values is constructed through theoretical calculations and electromagnetic simulations. Using ADS(Advanced Design System) software, 700 sets of simulation data are generated, with port power distribution ratios, maximum insertion loss, and maximum voltage standing wave ratio (VSWR) as inputs, and characteristic parameters as outputs, to train four independent DNN models. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed method effectively predicts the structural parameters of the power divider within the frequency range of 1.15–1.35 GHz. All performance metrics (insertion loss < 1 dB, VSWR < 1.5, isolation > 15 dB, phase balance ±5°) meet the design requirements, validating the feasibility and efficiency of neural networks in microwave device design.

title: A Study on the Application of YOLOPose in the Policing Psychological Training in Combat Situations
authors: Haitao Wang
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Computer Engineering (ICAICE)
abstract: A study on the application of YOLOPose in police psychological training in combat situations. Police tactical training, the posture of the trainee and clinical psychology is the focus of training, especially the trainee's posture changes can reflect the trainee's psychological situation, so as to find out the trainee's psycho-logical problems in the actual combat training, targeted adjustment of the training programme. The posture detection algorithm analyses the human body movement information in the image or video to extract the position and movement trajectory of the key points, so as to achieve the recognition and analysis of human body posture. It has important application value in many fields such as sports, traffic safety, medical treatment and so on, but there are few related researches in police tactical training, paper propose a research on the application of YOLOPose in police tactical training based on YOLOv5, to analyse the human body postures of the trainees in police tactical training, and to effectively improve the safety and timeliness of police tactical training. This gap highlights the need for intelligent, data-driven tools that can enhance the precision and safety of tactical training environments, where split-second decisions and accurate posture control are critical. The experimental conclusions show that the use of YOLOPose in police combat training can effectively detect the posture changes and psychological fluctuations of trainees, provide auxiliary decision-making for the detection of trainees' posture errors and clinical psychological problems, and significantly improve the safety and timeliness of police tactical training. By leveraging real-time pose estimation, the system aims to provide actionable feedback, reduce training injuries, and standardise tactical movements across different training scenarios.

title: Variational Bayesian Dehazing With Atmospheric Scattering Model for Synthetic-to-Real Generalization
authors: Stepan Babayan, Francisco Javier Sáez-Maldonado, Javier Mateos, Rafael Molina
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Image Processing Workshops (ICIPW)
abstract: Image dehazing is vital for enhancing visibility in applications like autonomous driving and surveillance, yet it remains challenging due to its ill-posed nature and the limitations of existing methods in real-world conditions. In this work, we introduce a variational Bayesian framework for single-image dehazing based on the atmospheric scattering model. Our approach effectively addresses complex haze characteristics, ensuring robust estimation of the haze-free image, transmission map, and atmospheric light. By integrating probabilistic deep learning with atmospheric scattering model-based techniques, our method, trained solely on synthetic data, achieves superior generalization on real-world datasets, outperforming state-of-the-art approaches trained on the same synthetic data and validated on both synthetic and real-world benchmarks.

title: Green Bond Default Risk Prediction Based on LSTM-Adaboost Classification Algorithm
authors: Juncheng Chen
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Computer Engineering (ICAICE)
abstract: Driven by the dual carbon goals, green finance has become a core force in promoting industrial structure upgrading and achieving ecological sustainable development. As a key tool for direct financing, the market size of green bonds has been steadily growing. However, as the issuers become increasingly diverse and the industry coverage continues to expand, some enterprises have encountered problems such as insufficient environmental protection information disclosure and a mismatch between ESG performance and financing purposes, gradually highlighting the default risk of green bonds. To this end, this paper proposes the LSTM-Adaboost fusion classification algorithm. Firstly, data features are mined through correlation analysis and violin graph analysis, and then comparative experiments are conducted with various machine learning algorithms such as decision tree, random forest, AdaBoost, KNN, XGBoost, and GBDT. The results show that the LSTM-Adaboost model performs the best in all evaluation indicators. The accuracy rate and recall rate both reach 86.5%, the precision rate is 83.7%, the F1 value is 83.8%, and the AUC value is 90.1%. The accuracy rate is 3 percentage points higher than that of the suboptimal GBDT model. It has significant advantages in the accuracy of positive and negative sample recognition, comprehensive classification efficiency and generalization ability. In the comparison models, GBDT performed outstandingly comprehensively, with XGBoost achieving an accuracy rate of 80.1%. However, the other models had performance shortcomings. This model, by integrating the sequence feature capture capability of LSTM with the integrated learning advantages of AdaBoost, effectively makes up for the deficiencies of traditional models in feature extraction depth and classification accuracy, providing an efficient technical solution for the precise prevention and control of green bond default risks. It has significant practical significance for consolidating the foundation of green finance development and ensuring the smooth progress of the dual carbon goals.

title: A Trajectory Planning and Control Method for Multi-Axis Synchronous Motion Scanning Mechanism
authors: Ai Zhang, Zhe Lin, Fengchao Liang, Lidong Jia, Jing Li, Xin Zhao, Yuanwei Jiu, Chao Zhang, Gang Huang
publish: 2025 IEEE 4th International Conference on Computing, Communication, Perception and Quantum Technology (CCPQT)
abstract: High-precision scanning mechanisms are critical components in space remote sensing cameras. To meet the requirements of remote sensing imaging, this study addresses the challenges of decoupling and high-precision control in multi-axis synchronous scanning systems. Existing deviation coupling control strategies suffer from limited synchronization performance and coupled tracking-following dynamics. This paper proposes a high-precision decoupling control algorithm for multi-axis scanning mechanisms in space cameras. The algorithm eliminates the influence of follower-axis disturbances on the master-axis control, achieving excellent synchronization and high control accuracy. It is applicable to various types of multi-axis scanning mechanisms in space cameras.

title: A Reinforcement Learning Method for Cyber Range Cloud Resource Scheduling
authors: Hongbin Zhang, Haibin Zhang, Chaoyang Ye
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Computer Engineering (ICAICE)
abstract: Currently, cyber ranges play a vital role in scientific research, production, and technological development. A critical challenge in these environments lies in the efficient scheduling of cloud service resources and the rapid deployment of corresponding supporting architectures. With the proliferation of intelligent technologies, artificial intelligence has emerged as a powerful and adaptive alternative for job scheduling and resource management. To address the computational constraints of single-node cloud servers that limit task scalability, this paper proposes a robust reinforcement learning framework for resource scheduling in cloud server environments, designed to enhance task scheduling and management capabilities. First, a resource scheduling model is established to capture computational resource profiles and data flow characteristics. Next, a deep reinforcement learning algorithm is applied to optimize resource allocation, thereby improving processing efficiency for large-scale tasks. Experimental simulations demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed approach.

title: SiC-Enabled DAB Converter for Battery Pack Active Balancing: Extensible Energy Management Framework for Electric Vehicles
authors: Guangze Sun, Dongze Li, Yunzhu Cao, Xusheng Wang, Abhisek Ukil, Akshya Swain
publish: 2025 IEEE PES 17th Asia-Pacific Power and Energy Engineering Conference (APPEEC)
abstract: This paper proposes an extensible active balancing framework for electric vehicle (EV) battery packs that combines a dual active bridge converter based on silicon carbide switches (SiC-DAB) with a reconfigurable switching array. The system achieves coordinated control through proportional-integral (PI)- regulated phase-shift modulation and dynamic state-of-charge (SOC)-based battery pack selection for adaptive power allocation. Simulation results show that the system achieves an efficiency of 96% at 50 kHz operating frequency and equalizes the SOC of four series-connected packs within about 12 minutes. This research provides a high-power-density, high-efficiency bidirectional active balancing solution for multi-pack battery systems in next-generation EV platforms.

title: Expert Operational Gans: Towards Real-Color Underwater Image Restoration
authors: Ozer Can Devecioglu, Serkan Kiranyaz, Mehmet Yamac, Moncef Gabbouj
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Image Processing Workshops (ICIPW)
abstract: The wide range of deformation artifacts that arise from complex light propagation, scattering, and depth-dependent attenuation makes the underwater image restoration to remain a challenging problem. Like other single deep regressor networks, conventional GAN-based restoration methods struggle to perform well across this heterogeneous domain, since a single generator network is typically insufficient to capture the full range of visual degradations. In order to overcome this limitation, we propose xOp-GAN, a novel GAN model with several expert generator networks, each trained solely on a particular subset with a certain image quality. Thus, each generator can learn to maximize its restoration performance for a particular quality range. Once a xOp-GAN is trained, each generator can restore the input image and the best restored image can then be selected by the discriminator based on its perceptual confidence score. As a result, xOP-GAN is the first GAN model with multiple generators where the discriminator is being used during the inference of the regression task. Experimental results on benchmark Large Scale Underwater Image (LSUI) dataset demonstrates that xOp-GAN achieves PSNR levels up to 25.16 dB, surpassing all single-regressor models by a large margin even, with reduced complexity.

title: ASCID-Net: A Unified Framework for Joint Imputation and Classification with Few Labels
authors: Chun Xie, Zerui Li, Shumi Zhao
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Computer Engineering (ICAICE)
abstract: Classification on data with both missing values and few labels is a persistent challenge in machine learning. To address this, this paper proposes ASCID-Net, a novel semi-supervised framework that unifies imputation and classification in an end-to-end manner by learning the joint distribution of features and labels. The framework integrates three core components: a dynamic autoregressive modeler to learn the joint data distribution, a label-guided transformation network to enhance feature representations using label signals, and a hybrid semi-supervised trainer to effectively leverage unlabeled data. Experiments on public datasets demonstrate the effectiveness and competitive performance of the proposed approach.

title: CAN Data-Processing, Diagnosis and Firmware Flashing Application Implementation using Python
authors: Ved Singh, Dhirendra Singh, Sachin Parandekar, Rohit Adake, Steve Francis, Azhan Farooqui
abstract: CAN is the networking system that a large number of vehicle categories utilize today because of its low cost, centralization and robustness. The CAN protocol is encapsulated within the ISO 11898 - (1 to 5). Raw CAN data however, is not usable for the end user. Most companies utilize DBC files to write debugging rules and utilize software to organize the processing of the data so as to be able to use the CAN logs for various applications (Fault Diagnosis, Preventative maintenance, AI related model training etc.). This paper focuses on a design workflow utilizing CAN python API's and Tkinter Design to construct an Executable that streamlines and simplifies this process so as to be able to be utilized by individuals with non-technical backgrounds.

title: Cross-Domain Computational Model: Joint Wavelet Subspace and Dual-Attention Mechanism for Hyperspectral Image Denoising
authors: Xinyi Li, Guangxian Xu, Fei Ma
publish: 2025 IEEE 4th International Conference on Computing, Communication, Perception and Quantum Technology (CCPQT)
abstract: The hyperspectral imaging system is inevitably affected by sensor noise and environmental interference during data acquisition, leading to noise contamination in the raw data,which poses significant challenges to the accuracy of subsequent computational tasks.To address the limited local receptive field issue of traditional Transformers in high-dimensional tensor computations, this paper proposes a cross-domain computational model: a denoising method combining wavelet subspace decomposition with a dual-attention mechanism.The method adopts an encoder-decoder architecture, which decomposes the input features into four parallel computational subspaces through Discrete Wavelet Transform (DWT), with the low-frequency component (LL) serving as the computational unit for transmitting fundamental features.In the wavelet domain, we design a Cooperative Dual-mode Attention Transformer (CDA-Transformer) that effectively integrates spectral and spatial information. Through a dynamic weight allocation mechanism, it achieves coordinated optimization of global context and local details. Experimental results on both ICVL and Urban datasets demonstrate that the proposed model delivers superior performance in denoising tasks.

title: AI-Driven Cybersecurity: Predictive Insights Into Attack Patterns and Effective Preventive Strategies
authors: Suhas Chavan, Rajneeshkaur Sachdeo
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Blockchain and Distributed Systems Security (ICBDS)
abstract: The tremendous growth of digital technology transformed several domains, making them increasingly susceptible to a growing spectrum of cyber-attacks. This paper investigates the multifacted picture of cyberattacks, and specifically of the adversarial threats, which leverage vulnerabilities within AI systems. As cyber attackers become more and more sophisticated with their attacks, the old cybersecurity defenses become less effective, thus highlighting an increased need for implementation of more defensive strategies. This paper provides a survey about different types of cyberattacks such as phishing, ransomware and adversarial attacks, that affect Aidriven systems and shows their impacts on such systems. Furthermore, the paper investigates advanced AI approaches for threat detection and response such as ML and deep learning which are used for fast discovery and suppression of new cyber threats. The article also stresses that a defense-in-depth approach combining AI capabilities and conventional security policies is required to mitigate the attack surface. Finally, this research attempts to advance the broader discussion on computer security by shedding light on the perils from adversarial attacks and by offering practical prevention strategies.

title: Emergency Communication Command and Dispatch Method Based on AI Agent
authors: Chao Zhang, Donghao Li, Linuo Zhang, Bin Dong
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Computer Engineering (ICAICE)
abstract: Emergency communication plays a vital and irreplaceable role in rescue and disaster relief. When natural disasters or emergencies occur, whether communication is unobstructed directly affects the success or failure of rescue operations and the safety of people's lives. Monitoring and early warning, and resource allocation play a crucial role in emergency communication, rescue, and disaster relief. Traditional emergency communication has the pain points of manual information capture and unintelligent command and dispatch. This paper designs an AI agent for emergency communication command and dispatch, which provides capabilities such as intelligent screening and identification of emergency communication information, information integration and association, intelligent dispatch of personnel and materials, decision support for command and dispatch, and automatic dispatch of emergency work orders. Meanwhile, a new emergency communication command and dispatch process was designed based on the proposed agent, which realized the automatic generation of emergency briefings, the automatic generation and dynamic adjustment of dispatch plans, and the automatic distribution of emergency work orders. The efficiency of emergency briefing editing and command and dispatch plan generation was increased by 82%, and the input of emergency communication on-duty personnel was reduced.

title: Multifunctional Landscapes and AI Validation as a Strategy to Enhance Creative Place-Making in Urban Voids
authors: Sahar Sadegh Malakabadi
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Knowledge Discovery in Concurrent Engineering (ICECONF)
abstract: Urban voids fragment the city fabric and erode civic identity, yet they also represent untapped opportunities for transformative urban design. This research demonstrates how multifunctional landscapes serve as powerful catalysts for urban revitalization by enhancing placemaking value in neglected spaces. Using a Tehran case study, rigorous statistical analyses were employed to identify critical design elements that significantly elevate community engagement and spatial cohesion. Water features emerged as the most influential design component <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{F}(2,320)=51.943;\mathrm{p} <$</tex>. 001, followed by artistic activities and social gathering spaces, elements that collectively achieved the highest placemaking scores (Mean = 32.565, n <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$=85)$</tex>. The strong correlation between water features and placemaking success illustrates deep cultural connections to the Persian garden tradition. This study provides empirical evidence that context-sensitive, multifunctional landscape strategies can optimize ecological services, strengthen social bonds, and enhance economic vitality, transforming problematic urban voids into vibrant community assets that advocate sustainable urban development.

title: Speed Control of DC Motor with Microcontroller Using Hand Gestures
authors: T.D. Sudhakar, R Nitish, H Aqeel, M Mohamed Askar, R R Prajesh, K Boopathy
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Knowledge Discovery in Concurrent Engineering (ICECONF)
abstract: This paper explores an innovative approach to adjusting the DC motor speed by hand gestures detected through a laptop camera, integrating image processing and microcontroller technology. Traditional methods of motor speed control often rely on physical interfaces like knobs, switches, or keypads. However, the proposed system leverages computer vision to interpret real-time hand movements, which are processed through software to generate appropriate signals. These indications are transmitted to a microcontroller (such as an Arduino), which adjusts the motor's speed via a motor driver. The goal is to generate a touch-free, intuitive control mechanism which enhances user interaction and reduces mechanical wear from physical components.

title: Anomaly-Oriented Multi-Class Intrusion Detection Using Machine Learning and Ensemble Methods
authors: Arya Jadhav, Aadi Parkhi, Manas Bhise, Shrey Bhandari, Amar Buchade, Santosh Kumar
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Blockchain and Distributed Systems Security (ICBDS)
abstract: This study evaluates six intrusion detection models using the UNSW-NB15 dataset, which serves as a modern benchmark encompassing diverse attack types and authentic traffic conditions. We analyze four traditional classifiers (Random Forest, XGBoost, SVM, and Logistic Regression), one deep learning approach (MLP + Autoencoder), and a stacking ensemble featuring RF, XGB, and SVM as base models with XGBoost as the meta model. Surprisingly, although ensemble and deep models are highly complex, Random Forest attained top macro-F1 and accuracy, especially performing well on minority classes. Preprocessing methods such as SMOTE and one-hot encoding played a significant role in feature balancing and encoding. Results point to RF as a robust, interpretable baseline. Future directions are diverse ensembles, hybrid DLML frameworks, and explainable AI.

title: A Lightweight Real-Time Dual-Metric System for Bicep Curl Form Correction
authors: Pradyumna Wagholikar, Ravindra B. Murumkar
publish: 2025 International Conference on NexGen Networks and Cybernetics (IC2NC)
abstract: Correct execution of strength-training exercises is critical for maximizing performance and minimizing injury risk. Automated systems that can monitor posture and provide immediate feedback are therefore of increasing importance in fitness applications. This research presents a real-time, vision-based system for the analysis and correction of bicep curl form, utilizing the MediaPipe Pose framework for landmark detection. The primary contribution is a dualmetric evaluation method that concurrently assesses the elbow flexion angle and the spatial stability of the elbow joint. This method enables the real-time identification of biomechanical errors, such as excessive joint displacement, while tracking repetitions based on adherence to a target angular range. The efficacy of this approach is validated through a quantitative analysis of captured motion data, which demonstrates a clear correlation between decreased joint stability and the terminal phases of flexion and extension. The framework operates in real time on standard consumer hardware, demonstrating the potential of lightweight vision-based systems for accessible fitness training.

title: Face Clustering Based on Local Identity Relation Estimation and Conservative Edge Expansion
authors: Jong-Hyeon Baek, Yeong Jun Koh
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Image Processing Workshops (ICIPW)
abstract: Face clustering aims to group unlabeled face images into identity-consistent clusters and is essential for large-scale face retrieval and dataset construction. However, existing graph-based methods often suffer from false positive connections and limited recall in complex feature spaces. This paper introduces a robust face clustering framework that addresses these challenges through two key components. First, the proposed local identity relation estimation network (LIRENet) verifies edge reliability by modeling both local context and identity-level interactions. Second, a neighborhood edge extension module adaptively expands the graph using shared neighbor constraints and similarity thresholds. The combination of these components enhances connectivity prediction while preserving cluster quality. Experimental results on MS-Celeb-1M, IJB-B, and DeepFashion demonstrate consistent improvements over previous state-of-the-art methods on both closed- and open-set benchmarks.

title: Intelligent Route Optimization Framework with IoT Integration for Efficient Waste Collection Trucks
authors: Nivethitha T, Abinav G, Dhanushwaran S, Gowshik M, Hanshan Kumar B, Hariharan S
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Evolutionary Computing and Mobile Sustainable Networks (ICECMSN)
abstract: Inefficient collection of the traditional waste is based on fixed routes and schedules with overflowing bins, fuel wastage and higher costs. In this paper, a proposal will be provided regarding an Internet of Things (IoT) intelligent route optimization framework that utilizes real-time sensor data, machine learning predictions, and dynamically planned routes. The system utilizes the ultrasonic and MQ-135 gas sensors to measure the fill and odor levels on waste containers that are connected to ESP32 microcontrollers. A real-time dashboard is available on a Flask basis and offers administration. A nearest-neighbor greedy algorithm is used to perform route optimization with a Haversine distance calculation and bin fill-time prediction is done with a Random Forest Regressor model using various environmental and temporal features. The finding of simulation shows that efficiency of routes can improve by 15-30 percent, using resources can be saved, and functioning can improve, which opens the way towards sustainable smart city waste management.

title: Location-Supported Lesions Representation with Potato Leaf Blight Disease Detection Using Dual-Head Convolutional Neural Network
authors: Y. V. Bhaskar Reddy, Imad Shalout, K. Latha, Rajkumar Bhookya, Swathi B, R. Premkumar
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Knowledge Discovery in Concurrent Engineering (ICECONF)
abstract: A deep learning framework designed for classifying potato leaf blight diseases using the Plant Village Dataset, we developed the Location-Supported Lesions Representation with Potato Leaf Blight Disease Detection Using Dual-Head Convolutional Neural Network (LLPLDC) model which consists of 2,152 processed images. To improve model generalization and tackle data imbalance, the dataset undergoes noise removal and augmentation. A Diffusion-based IGN-Net generates synthetic images of diseased leaves from healthy ones, the DH-CNN features dual outputs: one for identifying healthy versus diseased leaves and another for differentiating between early and late blight. Training utilizes stochastic gradient descent with learning rate adjustments and ReLU activations, enhancing classification accuracy. The confusion matrix, training and validation loss and accuracy of DHCNN and ROC curve are used to calculate the performance of LLPLDC.

title: “CryptoKalp”: A Tool for Cryptocurrency Investigation
authors: Sanjita Jain, Rupprashik Khare, Samyak Lahire, Chaitali Patil
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Blockchain and Distributed Systems Security (ICBDS)
abstract: There are more than over 23,000 cryptocurrencies” in existence which represent one of the biggest unregulated markets across the globe. Currently, each cryptocurrency utilises distinct public-private key and public address formats. This diversity complicates the investigator's task of tracing and verifying a suspect's involvement in cryptocurrency-related crimes. Moreover, law enforcement agencies such as the police frequently seize digital devices, generating digital disk images for investigation which is a time consuming process. Thus, the investigation of cryptocurrencies has emerged as a major challenge. for law enforcement agencies across the world. Our proposed solution “CryptoKalp” aims to combat cybercrimes involving cryptocurrencies. The essence of our proposed tool is encapsulated in its name: “CryptoKalp.” The name is a fusion of two significant terms - “crypto,” signifying cryptocurrency, and “kalp,” a Sanskrit word representing investigation [1]. Our proposed tool makes the investigation process quicker by taking digital images, strings, various formats of files and folders as input and utilising a comprehensive database of regular expressions covering various cryptocurrency public-private key and address formats. Currently, our tool successfully identifies Bitcoin public-private keys and addresses from text files, with future plans outlined expanding its capabilities for Ether, Tether, Monero, Dash and Dogecoin. Investigating officers can access the system's user-friendly interface and the database containing login credentials, cryptocurrency formats, and history of searched strings, which enables officers to track a specific criminal associated with a series of crypto transactions. Police can confirm whether a suspect is involved in cryptocurrency transactions and take necessary actions. Our solution will aid law enforcement authorities in combating cybercrime.

title: Unlocked Learning: How Educators Navigate AI in Open Education Spaces
authors: Abdelhak Senadjki, Hui-Nee Au Yong, Iddrisu Mohammed Awal, Samuel Ogbeibu
publish: 2025 International Workshop on Artificial Intelligence and Education (WAIE)
abstract: With the changing face of open learning because of the involvement of artificial intelligence (AI), the education sector is presented with new possibilities and intricate ambiguities. Although most of the existing discussions focus on technological innovation, the opinions of educators, who are the ones who are experiencing the influence of AI in pedagogy and access, have not been voiced yet. The proposed research seeks to address the question of how teachers of various backgrounds view and experience the use of AI in the open learning setting. A qualitative research design was used to gather data using in-depth interviews and focus group discussions with 30 educators selected in terms of disciplines, institutions, and regions. Five major themes have been uncovered: (1) AI tools are perceived as a means to improve administrative efficiency but not to substitute pedagogical judgment; (2) there are concerns about algorithmic bias, learner data privacy, and cultural neutrality; (3) AI-driven platforms can create digital divides unless equitably deployed; (4) educators want to have more agency and training in the adoption of AI; and (5) attitudes and preparedness toward AI depend heavily on disciplinary and regional contexts. The results indicate that inclusive AI policies should put a lot of emphasis on the voice of educators, contextual awareness, and lifelong learning. To make AI truly useful in open learning, systems should shift away from automation to supporting educators as co-designers of equitable, AI-enhanced learning.

title: AI based Assistive Device For Aphasia Elderly Patients
authors: N.N. Baalakumar, S. Prabakar, K.Mythili, N.Naveen, M.Sabharigirivasan, S.Mathan
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Evolutionary Computing and Mobile Sustainable Networks (ICECMSN)
abstract: Communication is a very crucial part of human interaction, and it enables people to express their ideas, wants, and feelings. Aphasia is a language disorder that is commonly caused by stroke or brain damages, which impairs speech comprehension and production, but cognitive and motor skills are generally unaffected. As a result, there are extreme communication barriers among the affected individuals in their everyday lives. This paper introduces an AI-supported communication system that combines the real-time hand gesture recognition with the text-to-speech features to support aphasic people. The Python based system which is implemented using OpenCV library uses a web camera to record and read the hand gestures, depending on the number of extended fingers. Every gesture is associated with a prepared verbal communication, e.g. one finger means I need water and two fingers I am hungry. The identified gestures are translated into audio both with the offline (pyttsx3) and online (Google Text-to-Speech) engines to provide the flexibility when different network conditions occur. The device is affordable, portable, and very easy to use and it only needs a normal computer and a webcam. It has a modular design whereby one can easily customize gestures and message mappings to suit personal requirements. The future products are to introduce machine learning based on dynamic gesture recognition, speech support in multiple languages and the implementation of the product on the mobile platform to increase its accessibility. The suggested system demonstrates the possibilities of computer and AI. mission to create all-inclusive, low-cost technologies that will contribute much to the quality of life of people with speech and language impairments.

title: Learning Single-Image Super-Resolution In The Jpeg Compressed Domain
authors: Sruthi Srinivasan, Elham Shakibapour, Rajy Rawther, Mehdi Saeedi
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Image Processing Workshops (ICIPW)
abstract: Deep learning models have grown increasingly complex, with input data sizes scaling accordingly. Despite substantial advances in specialized deep learning hardware, data loading continues to be a major bottleneck that limits training and inference speed. To address this challenge, we propose training models directly on encoded JPEG features, reducing the computational overhead associated with full JPEG decoding and significantly improving data loading efficiency. While prior works have focused on recognition tasks, we investigate the effectiveness of this approach for the restoration task of single-image super-resolution (SISR). We present a lightweight super-resolution pipeline that operates on JPEG discrete cosine transform (DCT) coefficients in the frequency domain. Our pipeline achieves a 2.6 x speedup in data loading and a 2.5 x speedup in training, while preserving visual quality comparable to standard SISR approaches.

title: Secure Healthcare Predictions via Homomorphic Encryption: A Privacy-Centric Framework
authors: Ashwini Kunal Bhavsar, Jaya Nag Mathur, Alaknanda S. Patil, Shweta G. Lilhare, Abhijit Hanumantrao Khadke, Vishal Borate
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Blockchain and Distributed Systems Security (ICBDS)
abstract: Providing privacy for data in healthcare analytics is a major challenge, especially when handling sensitive patient data. This paper introduces a privacy-preserving machine-learning framework utilizing Cheonimim Song (CKKS) Homomorphic Encryption to provide secure computation on encrypted medical data without divulging plaintext values. The proposed approach employs logistic regression to predict potential health risks with end-to-end encryption throughout the whole process. For additional protection of data in transit, a second level of Advanced Encryption Standard - Galois/Counter Mode (AES- GCM) encryption is applied. The experimental outputs demonstrate that the accuracy of the encrypted model is the same as the accuracy of the non-encrypted one, which confirms that homomorphic encryption may allow to do secure machine learning without significant performance degradation. Homomorphic encryption may increase the computation load, though; batch encoding and cipher text packing make it more efficient. These findings lead to the possibility of machine learning in encrypted medicine, and more research can be done to create safe medical AI systems.

title: Enhanced Underwater Image Visibility Using Adaptive Fusion Integrated with Local Intensity Filter
authors: Allaika Yadav, Dhruv Yadav, Sneha Arora, Vipin Kumar Sharma
abstract: This paper introduces a revolutionary underwater image enhancement method that employs an adaptive fusion framework utilizing a local intensity filter. The suggested procedure centers upon improving regional contrast and luminance dispersal since it integrates block-oriented intensity modulation which is steered via adjacency data, and this curtails lingering mist plus ocular anomalies. Mean Squared Error (MSE) as well as Peak Signal-to-Noise Ratio (PSNR) were utilized such that performance metrics could be evaluated across four test images. The results depict that MSE diminishes by 13.3% on average while PSNR gains climb up to 1.9%, also PSNR values get to 79.13 dB in the best instance. Considerably, the procedure improved the MSE regarding Image 2 via 27.8% also heightened definition substantially while conserving border honesty. Improved visual outcomes strengthen these numerical enhancements. The procedure is simple and yields superior renovation, appropriate for instantaneous subaquatic imagery applications. It is furthermore helpful to preparation in nautical robotics, archaeological recording, and submerged monitoring.

title: Cognitive Cyber Armor: AI-Driven Resilience against Intelligent Threat Actors
authors: Mohammad Majharul Islam Jabed, Muntaha Islam, Lamia Akter, Sharmin Ferdous, Sakera Begum, Amit Banwari Gupta
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Knowledge Discovery in Concurrent Engineering (ICECONF)
abstract: Substantial advancement of cyberattacks necessitates smart defense systems that have the ability to adjust to changing threat horizons. The following paper is about Cognitive Cyber Armor, an AI-based resilience model that uses sophisticated learning methods to neutralize intelligent threat agents. The suggested algorithm combines the Robust PCA to pre-process the data to remove noise and improve the signal quality, mRMR to select the features and maximize the relevant characteristics, and a Graph Attention Network classifier to detect the malicious actions. The system is implemented in Python with PyTorch and PyTorch Geometric and is associated with high accuracy in detection and low false-positives but better interpretability with regard to attention-based graph modeling. The results of the experiments point to its effectiveness in eliminating redundancy, achieving processing speed, and maintaining a strong performance even in adversarial situations. Cognitive Cyber Armor can be used to develop a scalable defense paradigm by integrating resilience, adaptability, and explainability, further developing proactive approaches to cybersecurity to secure against intelligent and adaptable cyber threats against major infrastructures.

title: Analysis of Kannada Tweets for Depression using Machine Learning Models
authors: V D Praveen, K Soorya Krishna, Smeely Mary Picardo, Aishwarya, Prashanth Kannadaguli
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Computing, Semiconductor, Mechatronics, Intelligent Systems and Communications (COSMIC)
abstract: The expanding role of social media has positioned platforms like X, Facebook, and WhatsApp as critical spaces for individuals to convey their thoughts and emotions instantaneously. This study focuses on the classifying users as depressive or non-depressive based on their social media posts in Kannada using machine learning techniques. Kannada’s distinct linguistic characteristics and scarcity of language resources create specific challenges for Natural Language Processing. In the present work, Machine Learning algorithms are used to find the indications of depressive thoughts of the user based on the tweets. This can then be used further for providing necessary aid and counselling to the depressed persons. A labelled dataset of Kannada tweets, adapted from the Sentiment140 corpus, was utilized in this study. Pre-processing techniques including tokenization, stop-word removal, vectorization and lemmatization using Word2Vec were applied. Logistic Regression, Extreme Gradient Boost, Ridge Classifier, Linear Discriminant Analysis and Stochastic Gradient Descent Classifier were trained using the vectorized dataset with their performance being evaluated using metrics accuracy and the Area Under the Curve score. The Linear Discriminant Analysis outperformed the chosen models with $79.95 \%$ accuracy.

title: Historical Frame and Motion Guided Diffusion Model for Video Anomaly Detection
authors: Rongxin Li, Xinlong Liu, Guangchao Wang, Bin Chen
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Measurement Control and Instrumentation (MCAI)
abstract: Video anomaly detection aims to identify events that deviate from normal behavior in surveillance videos. However, current methods still suffer from the long-range dependencies problem due to the limited capability in spatio-temporal modeling. In this paper, we propose HMDiff, a conditional diffusion model guided by the historical frames and motion features. In the HMDiff, videos are first compressed into discrete latent codes through a vector-quantized variational autoencoder (VQ-VAE). Then, vid3o frames are predicted in this latent space conditioned on the latent codes of historical frame and motion. Finally, anomalies are detected by the frame-level prediction error. Extensive experiments on UCSD Ped2, CUHK Avenue, and ShanghaiTech demonstrate that HMDiff achieves competitive performance compared with recent baselines, especially on long-temporal-range scenarios.

title: Design and Development of a RAG-Supported Chatbot Enhanced with RGC Prompt Method for Competency Assessment in Maritime Education
authors: Furkan Eyup Kizilay, Metin Celik
publish: 2025 International Workshop on Artificial Intelligence and Education (WAIE)
abstract: This study focuses on the preliminary design of a chatbot enhanced with a structured RGC prompt method based on Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) integrated with generative artificial intelligence (GAI) to assess the competencies of seafarers in maritime education. The chatbot system targets the IMO Model Courses $\mathbf{1. 2 0}$ and $\mathbf{2. 0 3}$ related to “Fire Prevention and Fire Fighting” and “Advanced Fire Fighting” under the Standards of Training, Certification and Watchkeeping for Seafarers (STCW), generating situational judgment test (SJT) scenarios aligned with STCW requirements. The chatbot, coded in Python and developed in a Docker environment with a PostgreSQL database, uses the Groq large language model (LLM) along with the Chainlit interface to analyze user queries and generate STCW compliant content. Thanks to the unique structure of the RGC method, the scenario creation process ensures suitability for maritime operations by considering roles, results, goals, context, and constraints. When the RGC prompt is entered into the system, the system generates scenarios, questions, and multiple-choice options for the user. This contributes to the development of competency assessment processes in maritime education. Future studies will include pilot applications to test the system’s validity and reliability, as well as the integration of other international maritime conventions.

title: Reinforcement Learning -Based Dynamic Pricing Framework for E-Commerce Revenue Growth
authors: Neelam Mohit Pashte, Chandni. M. C., Reshmi V Suresh, Niravkumar Rameshchandra Joshi, Praveen Rathod, Ranjitha Radhakrishna
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Knowledge Discovery in Concurrent Engineering (ICECONF)
abstract: Dynamic pricing has become one of the most important tactics of maximizing revenue within the context of e-commerce when consumers and competitor activity develop at an extremely high rate. This research suggests a Dynamic Pricing Framework that is based on Reinforcement Learning with the use of Deep Q-Networks (DQN) to make optimal price decisions in real time. Pricing problem is defined as a Markov Decision Process (MDP) where the states are the demand patterns, inventory levels and competitor prices and the actions are (price changes). The reward feature is seen to maximize revenue growth in the long term as opposed to the short-term. The framework is implemented with the help of TensorFlow and trains a deep neural network to produce approximations of Q-values, making it possible to implement adaptive pricing policies. Simulations of synthetic e-commerce data shows that the average revenue is dramatically improved when using the experimental simulation method over the traditional rule-based and demand-elasticity approaches. The findings point at the prospects of integrating reinforcement learning and scalable deep learning applications to design smart, competitive, customer-sensitive pricing systems of modern e-commerce platforms.

title: Comparative Study on Aeroelastic Control Laws for NACA 0012 and NACA 64A010
authors: Patcharaphon Koedprayodsuk, Nopdanai Ajavakom, Niphon Wansophark
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on Robotic Systems and Applications (ICRSA)
abstract: Flutter is an important factor that must be considered in airfoil design. One of the key indicators of flutter is the flutter speed, which represents the critical airspeed that may cause structural instability. This project aims to increase the flutter speed of airfoils using a control law. The study compares the control efficiency between two airfoils: NACA 0012 and NACA 64A010. The control method used in this study is gain feedback control, designed using the Linear-Quadratic Regulator (LQR) approach in MATLAB. The aerodynamic loads acting on the airfoils are calculated using the Theodorsen Unsteady Modeling while the flutter speed is determined using the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{P}-\mathbf{K}$</tex> method, which relies on the eigenvalues of a state-space system. The comparison is conducted at 120 % of the flutter speed for each airfoil. The results show that aeroelasticity control law for NACA 64A010 is more effective than aeroelasticity control law for NACA 0012. However, it is important to note that this study does not include thickness and shape airfoil. Future work should consider the thickness case to improve the accuracy of the analysis.

title: Site Selection and Capacity Allocation Strategy for Mobile Photovoltaic Charging Stations
authors: Hengli Zhang, Tianze Zheng, Jiaqi Hong, Yinuo Huang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Power System and Energy Internet (PoSEI)
abstract: Recent years, to achieve carbon peaking and carbon neutrality, the popularization of electric vehicles (EVs) makes great contributions to the reduction of carbon emissions. However, the charging behavior of large-scale EVs also brings great challenges to the safe and stable operation of the power system.
